body: Same here. My NestJS app now reports this warning during startup after upgrade to 0.2.26.

Are you using the Postgres pooling?

Are you able to replicate this with just typeorm?  If so, can you either create a repository that replicates this or instructions / snippet / etc so I can more easily replicate?

Yeah - given that the stack trace directly points at it - can see that is the line that's the problem.  Removing that line isn't going to work - it was intentionally included to prevent another issue we were having - where errors were being ignored pre-query.

Unfortunately, I cannot replicate this locally - so without a working replication through either a repository (or enough information to build a repository) it's a lot harder to debug this further.

A repository or some other means of replicating the issue could answer the following questions, but without that...

What postgres version are you using?
What node postgres client are you installing?
How are you connecting?
What's your ORMConfig like?
Are you using the pooling features?
When are you seeing this error?
Is it only during testing? If so, are you mocking out something somewhere?
Is it possible this is something to do with nest and not with typeorm?

* What postgres version are you using?â€˜
PostgreSQL 12.3 hosted by Docker.

* What node postgres client are you installing?
I'm sorry, I'm not a native English speaker, so I can't get the point.
If it refers to the Node.js pg module, the version is 8.3.3.

* How are you connecting?
API and DB are launched in the same network using docker-compose.
@nestjs/typeorm is installed in the API, and it connects to the DB through this. (and using same method in testing)

* What's your ORMConfig like?
It is the code of the setting part that works the same as ormconfig.json.
```
const ORM_CONFIG: TypeOrmModuleOptions = {
    type: 'postgres',
    url: process.env.DATABASE_URL,
    entities: [join(__dirname, '..', '..', 'libs', '**', '*.model.{ts,js}')],
    migrations: [
        join(
            __dirname,
            '..',
            '..',
            '..',
            'db',
            'migrations',
            '**',
            '*.{ts,js}',
        ),
    ],
    cli: {
        migrationsDir: 'db/migrations',
    },
    synchronize: false,
    logging: true,
    namingStrategy: new TypeOrmNamingStrategy(),
    // migrationsRun: true,
};
```
DATABASE_URL is set by docker-compose.yml as follows.
```
DATABASE_URL: postgresql://postgres:password@development-db/something_development
```

Or DB setting for testing.

```
const TESTING_ORM_CONFIG: TypeOrmModuleOptions = {
    type: 'postgres',
    url: process.env.DATABASE_TEST_URL,
    synchronize: false,
    dropSchema: false,
    entities: [
        join(__dirname, '..', '..', 'src', 'libs', '**', '*.model.{ts,js}'),
    ],
    migrations: [
        join(__dirname, '..', '..', 'db', 'migrations', '**', '*.{ts,js}'),
    ],
    cli: {
        migrationsDir: __dirname + '/../../db/migrations',
    },
    namingStrategy: new TypeOrmNamingStrategy(),
};

export = TESTING_ORM_CONFIG;
```

```
DATABASE_TEST_URL: postgresql://postgres:password@development-db/something_test
```


* Are you using the pooling features?
I haven't changed the DB settings manually, but please let me know if there is a way to check this just in case.

* When are you seeing this error?
I think it's time to start the e2e test and access to the DB.

* Is it only during testing? If so, are you mocking out something somewhere?
That's right. However, the e2e test does not mocking. Everything is actually connected to the DB and tested.

* Is it possible this is something to do with nest and not with typeorm?
I am investigating by fixing the version of nestjs, but when I return to v0.2.25, it works normally and it occurs again in v0.2.26, so I think nestjs is not very involved.
I'm trying to create a repository for reproduction.

I'm not sure if it will help but when I set 
**synchronize: false,**
in my orm config. This warning stops popping.

Looking through the code and thinking through it a bit -

Every single query we bind the listener to release on an error.  This is a bit weird because it means we end up binding this handler multiple times - especially if multiple queries fire off at the same time.  By default, 10 concurrent connections. That's could be why I didn't see this.

We could instead bind that listener when a new connection is made - in the `QueryRunner.connect` - and only set it up once.

However, without a way to replicate I can't confirm this would fix your issue.
Awesome!  I was able to use this to create a test for this.  I'll try to get that up, a fix against it, and in a PR today :)

issue.title: fix: prevent multiple `release` listeners in PostgresQueryRunner

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
move on-error-release code to the queryRunner connect function
so we only need to have one listener per query runner on each
connection - cutting down the number of listeners total &
preventing a problem with too many listeners

this edge case becomes a real problem within transactions where
the queries may be fired off on the same connection long before
they will eventually execute their callbacks

closes #6699

This is related to #6262 - it's a bit of a refactor of that code to handle
the case of transactions

issue.title: TypeOrm cause MaxListenersExceededWarning

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: TypeORM module for Nest framework (node.js)  ðŸ‡

issue.body:
With version 0.2.25 of TypeOrm, when I try to save 10 records at once using Repository.Save(), nodejs print the "MaxListenersExceededWarning".

Typeorm project owners already knows about "MaxListenersExceededWarning" with PGSQL server (exactly my case).
[Typeorm Issue Here](https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/pull/6708)

Actually i don't want to add manually the package typeorm@0.2.26, i prefer to let this library to include the right version of typeorm; so i will wait till a newer package version will be released which will include a newer package version of typeorm.
